revision.comment: Created page with "=Page Rank - How does Google Work= =Collatz Conjecture="
revision.text:
=Page Rank - How does Google Work=
=Collatz Conjecture=

=Page Rank - How does Google Work= =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi 
#collatz conguncture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113

=Page Rank - How does Google Work= =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture'' The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113

revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] [[File:rank1.png]] [[File:rank2.png]] [[File:rank3.png]] [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[File:rank9.png]] [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] [[File:rank2.png]] [[File:rank3.png]] [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[File:rank9.png]] [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations==

            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] [[File:rank2.png]] [[File:rank3.png]] [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[File:rank9.png]] [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:

Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29

revision.comment: /* Page Rank - How does Google Work */
revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? [[File:rank2.png]] [[File:rank3.png]] [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[File:rank9.png]] [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

revision.comment: /* Page Rank - How does Google Work */
revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[File:rank3.png]] [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[File:rank9.png]] [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)
==Output== ===For checkNum(2000)===

One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program==

revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[File:rank9.png]] [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:

checkNum(5000)

revision.comment: /* Page Rank - How does Google Work */
revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[File:rank9.png]] [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[File:rank9.png]] [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations==

        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

revision.comment: /* Page Rank - How does Google Work */
revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank8.png]] [[File:rank9.png]] [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations==

    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

revision.comment: /* Page Rank - How does Google Work */
revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] [[File:rank11.png]] [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)
==Output== ===For checkNum(2000)===

revision.comment: /* Page Rank - How does Google Work */
revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations==

    while(num!=1):

        else:

        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

revision.comment: /* Page Rank - How does Google Work */
revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the rank of page rank it is having. As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)
==Output== ===For checkNum(2000)===

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):

        if(num%2==0):

        iterations+=1

checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:

    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1

revision.comment: /* Page Rank - How does Google Work */
revision.text:
[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == [[File:rank12.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == [[File:rank12.png]] [[File:graph.png]] [[File:graph1.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29

        else:

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == [[File:rank12.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == [[File:rank12.png]] [[File:graph.png]] [[File:graph1.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == [[File:rank12.png]] [[File:graph00.png]] [[File:graph01.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations==

Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png]] [[File:graph00.png]] [[File:graph01.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1

def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png]] [[File:graph00.png]] [[File:graph01.png]] ==Gragh Drawing Program== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29

def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png]] [[File:graph00.png]] [[File:graph01.png]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png]] ==Gragh Drawing Program2== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph004.png]] ==Gragh Drawing Program3== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(5,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(5,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph005.png]] ==Complete Graph== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.complete_graph(4)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:completegraph001.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29

            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

Output: [[File:completegraph001.png]] ==Cycle graph== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.cycle_graph(5)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:cyclegraph1.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png]] [[File:graph00.png]] [[File:graph01.png]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png]] ==Gragh Drawing Program2==

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph004.png]] ==Gragh Drawing Program3==

plt.show()

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png]] [[File:graph00.png]] [[File:graph01.png]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png]] ==Gragh Drawing Program2== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph004.png|400px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program3==

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.barbell_graph(5,3)

plt.show()

G=nx.complete_graph(4)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:completegraph001.png]] ==Cycle graph==

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.cycle_graph(5)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:cyclegraph1.png]] ==Ladder graph==

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.ladder_graph(5)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:laddergraph.png]] ==Path Graph== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.path_graph(6)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:pathgraph.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program2== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph004.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program3== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(5,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(5,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph005.png]] ==Complete Graph== Complete graph is a graph, wherein, each node is connected to each other nodes in a graph. 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.complete_graph(4)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:completegraph001.png]] ==Cycle graph== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.cycle_graph(5)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:cyclegraph1.png]] ==Ladder graph== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.ladder_graph(5)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:laddergraph.png]] ==Path Graph== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.path_graph(6)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:pathgraph.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

Output: [[File:pathgraph.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)
