[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program2==

G=nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph004.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program3==

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program2== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph004.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program3==

plt.show()

plt.show()
Output: [[File:cyclegraph1.png|600px]] ==Ladder graph==

G=nx.path_graph(6)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:pathgraph.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png]] [[File:collatz2.png]] [[File:collatz3.png]] [[File:collatz4.png]] [[File:collatz5.png]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program2== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph004.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program3== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(5,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(5,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph005.png|600px]] ==Complete Graph== Complete graph is a graph, wherein, each node is connected to each other nodes in a graph. 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.complete_graph(4)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:completegraph001.png|600px]] ==Cycle graph==

G=nx.cycle_graph(5)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:cyclegraph1.png|600px]] ==Ladder graph== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.ladder_graph(5)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:laddergraph.png|600px]] ==Path Graph== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.path_graph(6)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:pathgraph.png|600px]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program2==

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph004.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program3==

G=nx.barbell_graph(5,3)

plt.show()

Output: [[File:wheelgraph.png]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

=Collatz Conjecture=
Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi

If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. 

[[File:collatz1.png|600px]]

[[File:collatz2.png|600px]]

[[File:collatz3.png|600px]]

[[File:collatz4.png|600px]]

[[File:collatz5.png|600px]]

Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. 



The program to implement the same is as follows:
==Program==

#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113





#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29



==Program adding statement to print all iterations==

def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()

Output: [[File:wheelgraph6nodes.png|600px]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:Graph003.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program2==

G=nx.barbell_graph(4,3)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()

Output: [[File:randomgraph.png|600px]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

[[File:randomgraph2.png|600px]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

nx.draw(G)
plt.show()

[[File:randomgraph2.png|600px]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1== 
import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
G=nx.barbell_graph(4,2)
nx.draw(G)
plt.show()

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

nx.draw(G)
plt.show()

Output: [[File:randomDirectedGraphwithLabels.png|600px]] =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

Output: [[File:randomDirectedGraphwithLabels.png|600px]] ==Page Rank Coding== 
import networkx as nx
import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import operator

#Draw random directed graph 
G=nx.gnp_random_graph(10,0.5,directed=True)
#Give label numbering to nodes
nx.draw(G,with_labels=True)
plt.show()

#x is the random source node
x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])

#dictionary to maintain counter
dictCounter={}
#initialize the counter of each node as 0
for i in range(G.number_of_nodes()):
    dictCounter[i]=0
dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

for i in range(10000):
    listn=list(G.neighbors(x))
    #if x is a sink node, we need to select random node for random walk
    #, else select random neighbor node

    if(len(listn)==0):
        x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1
    else:
        #choose a node randomly from neightbors
        x=random.choice(listn)
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

p=nx.pagerank(G)
sorted_p=sorted(p.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))
sorted_rw=sorted(dictCounter.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))                        
#print(p)
#print(dictCounter)

print(sorted_p)
print(sorted_rw)
Output: 
[(2, 0.07139920240302768), (5, 0.07464882519777695), (3, 0.08527469366832419), (6, 0.08665188647066119), (4, 0.0987815549542114), (0, 0.10858415997562518), (9, 0.110369696943925), (8, 0.11456211367660116), (1, 0.11682018308814024), (7, 0.13290768362170685)]
[(2, 4), (5, 7), (8, 7), (6, 8), (3, 11), (7, 11), (1, 12), (4, 12), (0, 13), (9, 16)]

#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1

        if(num%2==0):

        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

    elif num%2==0:

    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

plt.show()

import networkx as nx
import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import operator

#Draw random directed graph 
G=nx.gnp_random_graph(10,0.5,directed=True)
#Give label numbering to nodes
nx.draw(G,with_labels=True)
plt.show()

#x is the random source node
x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])

#dictionary to maintain counter
dictCounter={}
#initialize the counter of each node as 0
for i in range(G.number_of_nodes()):
    dictCounter[i]=0
dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

for i in range(10000):
    listn=list(G.neighbors(x))
    #if x is a sink node, we need to select random node for random walk
    #, else select random neighbor node

    if(len(listn)==0):
        x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1
    else:
        #choose a node randomly from neightbors
        x=random.choice(listn)
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

p=nx.pagerank(G)
sorted_p=sorted(p.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))
sorted_rw=sorted(dictCounter.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))                        
#print(p)
#print(dictCounter)

print(sorted_p)
print(sorted_rw)
Output: 
[(2, 0.07139920240302768), (5, 0.07464882519777695), (3, 0.08527469366832419), 
(6, 0.08665188647066119), (4, 0.0987815549542114), (0, 0.10858415997562518), 
(9, 0.110369696943925), (8, 0.11456211367660116), (1, 0.11682018308814024), 
(7, 0.13290768362170685)]
[(2, 4), (5, 7), (8, 7), (6, 8), (3, 11), (7, 11), (1, 12), (4, 12), (0, 13), (9, 16)]
=Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

import networkx as nx
import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import operator

#Draw random directed graph 
G=nx.gnp_random_graph(10,0.5,directed=True)
#Give label numbering to nodes
nx.draw(G,with_labels=True)
plt.show()

#x is the random source node
x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])

#dictionary to maintain counter
dictCounter={}
#initialize the counter of each node as 0
for i in range(G.number_of_nodes()):
    dictCounter[i]=0
dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

for i in range(10000):
    listn=list(G.neighbors(x))
    #if x is a sink node, we need to select random node for random walk
    #, else select random neighbor node

    if(len(listn)==0):
        x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1
    else:
        #choose a node randomly from neightbors
        x=random.choice(listn)
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

p=nx.pagerank(G)
sorted_p=sorted(p.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))
sorted_rw=sorted(dictCounter.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))                        
#print(p)
#print(dictCounter)

print(sorted_rw)

=Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

nx.draw(G)
plt.show()

import networkx as nx
import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

#Draw random directed graph 
G=nx.gnp_random_graph(10,0.5,directed=True)
#Give label numbering to nodes
nx.draw(G,with_labels=True)
plt.show()
Output: [[File:randomDirectedGraphwithLabels.png|600px]] ===Page Rank Coding=== 
import networkx as nx
import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import operator

#Draw random directed graph 
G=nx.gnp_random_graph(10,0.5,directed=True)
#Give label numbering to nodes
nx.draw(G,with_labels=True)
plt.show()

#x is the random source node
x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])

#dictionary to maintain counter
dictCounter={}
#initialize the counter of each node as 0
for i in range(G.number_of_nodes()):
    dictCounter[i]=0
dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

for i in range(10000):
    listn=list(G.neighbors(x))
    #if x is a sink node, we need to select random node for random walk
    #, else select random neighbor node

    if(len(listn)==0):
        x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1
    else:
        #choose a node randomly from neightbors
        x=random.choice(listn)
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

p=nx.pagerank(G)
sorted_p=sorted(p.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))
sorted_rw=sorted(dictCounter.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))                        
#print(p)
#print(dictCounter)

print(sorted_p)
print(sorted_rw)
Output: 
[(2, 0.07139920240302768), (5, 0.07464882519777695), (3, 0.08527469366832419), 
(6, 0.08665188647066119), (4, 0.0987815549542114), (0, 0.10858415997562518), 
(9, 0.110369696943925), (8, 0.11456211367660116), (1, 0.11682018308814024), 
(7, 0.13290768362170685)]
[(2, 4), (5, 7), (8, 7), (6, 8), (3, 11), (7, 11), (1, 12), (4, 12), (0, 13), (9, 16)]
=Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1

def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

Output: [[File:randomDirectedGraphwithLabels.png|600px]] ===Page Rank Coding=== 
import networkx as nx
import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import operator

#Draw random directed graph 
G=nx.gnp_random_graph(10,0.5,directed=True)
#Give label numbering to nodes
nx.draw(G,with_labels=True)
plt.show()

#x is the random source node
x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])

#dictionary to maintain counter
dictCounter={}
#initialize the counter of each node as 0
for i in range(G.number_of_nodes()):
    dictCounter[i]=0
dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

for i in range(10000):
    listn=list(G.neighbors(x))
    #if x is a sink node, we need to select random node for random walk
    #, else select random neighbor node

    if(len(listn)==0):
        x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1
    else:
        #choose a node randomly from neightbors
        x=random.choice(listn)
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

p=nx.pagerank(G)
sorted_p=sorted(p.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))
sorted_rw=sorted(dictCounter.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))                        
#print(p)
#print(dictCounter)

print(sorted_p)
print(sorted_rw)
Output: 
[(2, 0.07139920240302768), (5, 0.07464882519777695), (3, 0.08527469366832419), 
(6, 0.08665188647066119), (4, 0.0987815549542114), (0, 0.10858415997562518), 
(9, 0.110369696943925), (8, 0.11456211367660116), (1, 0.11682018308814024), 
(7, 0.13290768362170685)]
[(2, 4), (5, 7), (8, 7), (6, 8), (3, 11), (7, 11), (1, 12), (4, 12), (0, 13), (9, 16)]
=Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

plt.show()

import networkx as nx
import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import operator

#Draw random directed graph 
G=nx.gnp_random_graph(10,0.5,directed=True)
#Give label numbering to nodes
nx.draw(G,with_labels=True)
plt.show()

#x is the random source node
x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])

#dictionary to maintain counter
dictCounter={}
#initialize the counter of each node as 0
for i in range(G.number_of_nodes()):
    dictCounter[i]=0
dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

for i in range(10000):
    listn=list(G.neighbors(x))
    #if x is a sink node, we need to select random node for random walk
    #, else select random neighbor node

    if(len(listn)==0):
        x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1
    else:
        #choose a node randomly from neightbors
        x=random.choice(listn)
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

p=nx.pagerank(G)
sorted_p=sorted(p.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))
sorted_rw=sorted(dictCounter.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))                        
#print(p)
#print(dictCounter)

print(sorted_p)
print(sorted_rw)
Output: 
[(2, 0.07139920240302768), (5, 0.07464882519777695), (3, 0.08527469366832419), 
(6, 0.08665188647066119), (4, 0.0987815549542114), (0, 0.10858415997562518), 
(9, 0.110369696943925), (8, 0.11456211367660116), (1, 0.11682018308814024), 
(7, 0.13290768362170685)]
[(2, 4), (5, 7), (8, 7), (6, 8), (3, 11), (7, 11), (1, 12), (4, 12), (0, 13), (9, 16)]
[[#Top]] =Email communication Network= =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

import networkx as nx

#Give label numbering to nodes

#x is the random source node
x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])

#dictionary to maintain counter
dictCounter={}
#initialize the counter of each node as 0
for i in range(G.number_of_nodes()):
    dictCounter[i]=0
dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

for i in range(10000):
    listn=list(G.neighbors(x))
    #if x is a sink node, we need to select random node for random walk
    #, else select random neighbor node

    if(len(listn)==0):
        x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1
    else:
        #choose a node randomly from neightbors
        x=random.choice(listn)
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

p=nx.pagerank(G)

sorted_rw=sorted(dictCounter.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))

print(sorted_rw)

import networkx as nx
import random
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import operator

#Draw random directed graph 
G=nx.gnp_random_graph(10,0.5,directed=True)
#Give label numbering to nodes
nx.draw(G,with_labels=True)
plt.show()

#x is the random source node
x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])

#dictionary to maintain counter
dictCounter={}
#initialize the counter of each node as 0
for i in range(G.number_of_nodes()):
    dictCounter[i]=0
dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

for i in range(10000):
    listn=list(G.neighbors(x))
    #if x is a sink node, we need to select random node for random walk
    #, else select random neighbor node

    if(len(listn)==0):
        x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1
    else:
        #choose a node randomly from neightbors
        x=random.choice(listn)
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

p=nx.pagerank(G)
sorted_p=sorted(p.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))
sorted_rw=sorted(dictCounter.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))                        
#print(p)
#print(dictCounter)

print(sorted_p)
print(sorted_rw)
Output: 
[(2, 0.07139920240302768), (5, 0.07464882519777695), (3, 0.08527469366832419), 
(6, 0.08665188647066119), (4, 0.0987815549542114), (0, 0.10858415997562518), 
(9, 0.110369696943925), (8, 0.11456211367660116), (1, 0.11682018308814024), 
(7, 0.13290768362170685)]
[(2, 4), (5, 7), (8, 7), (6, 8), (3, 11), (7, 11), (1, 12), (4, 12), (0, 13), (9, 16)]
[[#Top]] =Email communication Network= =Collatz Conjecture= Taught by Sudarshan sir and Amit sir, and Edited by Ms. Ami Tusharkant Choksi If a number is even, divide it by ''2'', if it is odd, make multiply it by ''3'' and add ''1'', till you get ''1''. This simple problem is called, ''Collatz Conjecture''. [[File:collatz1.png|600px]] [[File:collatz2.png|600px]] [[File:collatz3.png|600px]] [[File:collatz4.png|600px]] [[File:collatz5.png|600px]] Number is bigger doesn't mean more iterations are required. One can notice, from the output of the following program. The program to implement the same is as follows: ==Program== 
#collatz conjecture
#if num is even, divide it by 2
#if num is odd, new number is equal to 3n+1


def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)


#checkNum(12)#Output: 1 10
#checkNum(26)#Output: 1 11
checkNum(2000)#Output: 1 113


#recursive approach

def checkNum(num):
    if num==1:
        return 1
    elif num%2==0:
        return checkNum(num/2)+1
    else:
        return checkNum(3*num +1)+1


output:
checkNum(26)
Out[27]: 11
checkNum(5000)
Out[28]: 29
==Program adding statement to print all iterations== 
def checkNum(num):
    iterations=1
    while(num!=1):
        if(num%2==0):
            num=int(num/2)            
        else:
            num = 3*num+1
        print(iterations,":",num)
        iterations+=1
        

    print(num,iterations)

[http://sccilabs.org/jocwiki/index.php/Special:Contributors/Lecture_Notes:_Week_12 Contributors of this page] =Page Rank - How does Google Work= One web page is having link to other page, that is a page is referring to other page. Google uses ''Page Rank'' algorithm to choose which page should be displayed first. If we have network, connections as below: [[File:rank0.png]] We want to pick a leader out of all these nodes. How to pick a leader? Why to elect a leader? It is because we want to find the super power of available nodes. [[File:rank1.png]] For example, the application wherein, we want to find the most impressive person of the few ones. How to decide it? As shown in below figure, each node will communicate with other, randomly, we implement the count for each node, how many times, the particular node is being visited. [[File:rank2.png]] [[#Top]] As shown in following, figure, all nodes are visited and each node is marked with the number i.e.number of times the node is visited. [[File:rank3.png]] The node with the maximum count, becomes the winner. Here, node with 120 count in figure below, is the winner. i.e. The person with 120 count in the figure is the most impressive person in the community being considered. [[File:rank4.png]] [[File:rank5.png]] [[File:rank6.png]] [[File:rank7.png]] [[File:rank8.png]] [[#Top]] Google selects the page rank in this matter. Each web page is connected to other web page with web links. To a page, maximum link is there, that will be put on top results in Google search results. [[File:rank9.png]] Google uses web crawler. The crawler takes the random walk on the www network and rank the web sites. [[File:rank10.png]] This way Google ranks the pages and displays search results, according to page rank. [[File:rank11.png]] e.g.we search for ''mysore city''. Google has 10,000 results. But it displays the results in the sequence of page rank of search results, As shown in figure below. [[File:mysore.png]] [[#Top]] ==Page rank algorithm == As shown in beautiful figure below, few nodes combinely selected one as the leader, then that leader and other nodes, have selected other as a leader. This way, finally the final leader is elected. [[File:rank12.png|600px]] [[File:graph00.png|600px]] [[File:graph01.png|600px]] ==Gragh Drawing Program1==

x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])

#dictionary to maintain counter
dictCounter={}
#initialize the counter of each node as 0
for i in range(G.number_of_nodes()):
    dictCounter[i]=0
dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

for i in range(10000):
    listn=list(G.neighbors(x))
    #if x is a sink node, we need to select random node for random walk
    #, else select random neighbor node

    if(len(listn)==0):
        x=random.choice([i for i in range(G.number_of_nodes())])
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1
    else:
        #choose a node randomly from neightbors
        x=random.choice(listn)
        dictCounter[x]=dictCounter[x]+1

p=nx.pagerank(G)
sorted_p=sorted(p.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))
sorted_rw=sorted(dictCounter.items(),key=operator.itemgetter(1))                        
#print(p)
#print(dictCounter)

print(sorted_rw)
